articles.headline: Russia Could Use Cryptocurrency to Blunt the Force of U.S. Sanctions
articles.snippet: Russian companies have many cryptocurrency tools at their disposal to evade sanctions, including a so-called digital ruble and ransomware.
articles.abstract: Russian companies have many cryptocurrency tools at their disposal to evade sanctions, including a so-called digital ruble and ransomware.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the United States barred Americans from doing business with Russian banks, oil and gas developers and other companies in 2014, after the country’s invasion of Crimea, the hit to Russia’s economy was swift and immense. Economists estimated that sanctions imposed by Western nations cost Russia $50 billion a year.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: What Does Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine Mean for the U.S. Economy?
articles.snippet: The Russian attack on Ukraine could push up oil and food prices globally at a time of already-high inflation. In the U.S., it will drive up uncertainty.
articles.abstract: The Russian attack on Ukraine could push up oil and food prices globally at a time of already-high inflation. In the U.S., it will drive up uncertainty.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine could have economic repercussions globally and in the United States, ramping up uncertainty, roiling commodity markets and potentially pushing up inflation as gas and food prices rise around the world.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Many Russians Feel a Deep Unease Over Going to War
articles.snippet: After months of tuning out American warnings that Vladimir Putin was preparing to invade Ukraine, Russians now realize that “this is not a game.”
articles.abstract: After months of tuning out American warnings that Vladimir Putin was preparing to invade Ukraine, Russians now realize that “this is not a game.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage on Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: White House Prepares Curbs on Russia’s Access to U.S. Technology
articles.snippet: Biden administration officials have warned Russia that it could face further restrictions on technology that is critical to its economy and military.
articles.abstract: Biden administration officials have warned Russia that it could face further restrictions on technology that is critical to its economy and military.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration warned on Wednesday that it had prepared additional measures aimed at cutting off Russia from advanced technology critical to its economy and military in the event of further aggression by President Vladimir V. Putin toward Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Putin Announces Start to ‘Military Operation’ Against Ukraine
articles.snippet: “The invasion has begun,” Ukraine’s Interior Ministry said. Putin says he seeks “demilitarization” of Ukraine but has no plans to occupy it.
articles.abstract: “The invasion has begun,” Ukraine’s Interior Ministry said. Putin says he seeks “demilitarization” of Ukraine but has no plans to occupy it.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia declared the start of a “special military operation” in Ukraine on Thursday, after months of speculation about Russia’s intentions as it massed tens of thousands of troops on Ukraine’s border.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Stocks and Energy Markets Whipsaw After Russian Attack on Ukraine
articles.snippet: Stocks in Europe were sharply lower, but the S&P 500 rebounded after an early decline. Energy markets swung wildly, and shares in Moscow collapsed.
articles.abstract: Stocks in Europe were sharply lower, but the S&P 500 rebounded after an early decline. Energy markets swung wildly, and shares in Moscow collapsed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices and global stock markets swung wildly on Thursday after Russia launched an invasion of Ukraine, raising fears of a wider economic crisis that could follow.
articles.byline: By Jeff Sommer and Kevin Granville

articles.headline: Say Hello Again to the Office, Fingers Crossed
articles.snippet: Antsy executives have a message for their employees: Plans to return to in-person work are real this time.
articles.abstract: Antsy executives have a message for their employees: Plans to return to in-person work are real this time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives at the investment firm TIAA are especially proud of one aspect of their back-to-work plans: The company is on only its second round of setting a return-to-office date. They first hoped to bring employees back in January, but were derailed by the Omicron variant. Now the firm is targeting March 7.

articles.headline: Accurate U.S. intelligence did not stop Putin, but it gave Biden big advantages.
articles.snippet: The depth and quality of the intelligence strengthened the president’s hand in persuading allies to form a unified front against Moscow.
articles.abstract: The depth and quality of the intelligence strengthened the president’s hand in persuading allies to form a unified front against Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States intelligence agencies unearthed Russia’s war plans. They accurately assessed President Vladimir V. Putin’s intentions and, through strategic public releases of information, complicated his efforts to create a pretext to send his armed forces into Ukraine. They got the timing of his invasion right almost to the hour.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Russians Now See a New Side to Putin: Dragging Them Into War
articles.snippet: The autocrat who has steered Russia for 22 years was embraced by many Russians for what they saw as his rationality and astute risk management. That image has been upended.
articles.abstract: The autocrat who has steered Russia for 22 years was embraced by many Russians for what they saw as his rationality and astute risk management. That image has been upended.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russians thought they knew their president.

articles.headline: Zelensky Steps Into a Role Few Expected: Ukraine’s Wartime President
articles.snippet: Even as doubts have lingered about his preparedness to lead, Volodymyr Zelensky, a former actor, gave the performance of his life as Russian forces prepared to invade.
articles.abstract: Even as doubts have lingered about his preparedness to lead, Volodymyr Zelensky, a former actor, gave the performance of his life as Russian forces prepared to invade.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — He appeared on Ukrainian television early on Thursday morning, as the threat of war was pressing down. First, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addressed the 44 million citizens of Ukraine. Then he turned to the 144 million Russians living next door and beseeched them to prevent an attack that evoked the darkest eras in Europe since World War II.
